div1.p: Reed has his uniform tailored for a photograph to give to Emilie Lawrence. He makes plans to visit her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, June 21, 1875
div1.p:
Punctually
as the hands of Time reach the
hour of 8 o'clock, I am seated
at my writing-desk ready to
begin my semi-weekly epistle.
I am afraid that this, the very
first one, will be a failure, but
after hearing my excuses, I don't
think you will find any room
in your darling heart for crit-
icism. Now listen -- This letter
must be written and mailed be-
fore Eleven o'clock -- Well, I hear
you say, “Land of the free! isn't
there plenty of time from 8 to
11 to write a letter”? Yes, quite
enough, especially when the
heart is so thoroughly enlisted &
the hand so ready to obey.
But at 9 o'cl'k, I have a very
important engagement to meet,
it being nothing less than one
with my military tailor, & upon
my punctuality a great deal
depends. For if my coat is not
properly remodelled, I can't
have any photographs taken,
and if none are taken, none
will be sent, & if none are
sent, I'll be miserable & you,
my darling, (I scarcely know
what to say) will not get one!
Now you see what a string
of “ifs” there are, all of which
can only be demolished by
my prompt attendance at 9 o.c.
I have still another reason-
able excuse. It so happens,
that in this edifice there is but
one ink-stand- As the Orator
exclaimed, “it stands solus &
alone”- Its appearance is
very humble & unpretending,
but yet it is in constant demand-
I never had very much respect
for it, till this morning, but
now I don't believe it has its
superior in the land- The reason
of my sudden admiration is
owing to the fact that my moth-
er is constantly calling for this
ink-stand, as she, too, is very
anxious to write to her sweet-
heart- You may wonder why
we don't both use it, at one
& the same time -- Why, for the
very reason that she would
read my letter as fast as I
write it- Indeed, she has made
a few desperate attempts
to read my letters since my
return, & especially has she
desired to see how I begin
them- Whether I call you, “my
darling, my sweet, my pre-
cious, my ever adorable, my
never-to-be-forgotten,” or whatever
it may be- I tell her that I
commence them simply, “Miss
Lawrence;” but she professes
too much wisdom s to be thus
easily duped & declares that
I am the most unaccommodating
boy she ever knew- I tell her
that in order to see how I be-
gin my letters, she must write
to you & ask your permission,
as I never do anything without
first consulting your wishes.
Her only answer is, that “she'll
be switched if she does any such
thing”! What this means, I am at
a loss to say. (Ah!, my darling,
with all her “switchings”, she is
a dear good mother- Every evening,
she, Mrs. V. & I sit on the front
porch & talk of you, & such
sweet talks as we have;! I
trust that they may never fade
from my memory.) So that be-
tween my pressing engagement
& a restless ink-holder, you
must excuse the hurry of my
letter- In my last, I spoke of
my intention of writing to
your mother & asking her con-
sent to my engagement with her
youngest & sweetest daughter-
After sealing my letter, It oc-
curred to me to delay writing
till I could hear from you &
learn your wishes in regard
to the matter- You know, my darl-
ing, that you deprived me of one
opportunity of having a talk
with your mother, & since I missed
the chance of a conversation,
the only remaining alternative
is to write & ask her consent-
You will agree with me that
it would only be showing her
that respect which her position,
as your mother, calls for. Be-
sides, I should feel so much
better satisfied, with the knowl-
edge of her approval. (The clock
has struck 9 & I must ask to be
excused for a short while)

10 o'clock, and I am ready to continue
my letter-

Before I forget it, I must
speak of a matter that has just
occurred to me- My mother, a few
days ago, during a conversation,
said that she had heard you say
that you would prefer being en-
gaged with a bracelet rather
than a ring. Is this the case?
I believe I have heard of such
but am not certain. I have but
one desire in the matter & that
is to abide your good pleasure-
If you prefer the bracelet, it
would afford me very great pleasure
to complying with your wishes.
Don't forget, in your next letter,
to speak of this- You will be
surprised to learn that I have
heard from you since I received
your last letter- A certain gen-
tleman, who has been in M. a
few days, never writes home
but that he sends some
message- He said that Mr. Dr
Lawrence told him what you
answered, when he asked if you
if he should send a young gen-
tleman to escort you to College.
“His son” is very much gratified
with the compliment & only re-
grets that he was not present
to say, “Amen”- You need not ex-
press any particular surprise
if you chance to see any one
resembling myself passing along
your streets- My precious An-
gel, I am so continually pres-
ent in mind with you all the
while, that it would be no great miracle
if I should appear in body.
It may be that I shall appear,
in body and mind, in your
town within the next few
weeks- If my route should carry me
in that direction, I'll surely come-
div1.closer:
Till then believe, as ever, darling, your affectionate &
ever devoted, Walter-
P.S. Ma sends
her best love,
& declares that
she will come
to Murfreesboro
soon, if you do
not answer her
letter-
W.R.
